intro: Scirpus xerophilus, commonly known as the drought-loving sedge, is a perennial plant native to arid and semi-arid regions. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges, and is characterized by its triangular stems and grass-like leaves. This plant is adapted to thrive in dry conditions, with a deep root system that helps it access moisture from deeper soil layers. Its flowering spikes produce small, pale green to brown flowers, which are typically wind-pollinated. Scirpus xerophilus plays a role in stabilizing soils in its native habitats and is often found in disturbed or degraded landscapes.
